results.adx_keywords: Elder Care;Dementia;Alzheimer's Disease;Nursing Homes;Group Homes and Supportive Housing;Weesp (Netherlands);Baerum (Norway);Bellmere (Australia);Europe;Australia
results.title: As Cases Soar, ‘Dementia Villages’ Look Like the Future of Home Care
results.abstract: A new generation of treatment facilities is aiming to integrate dementia patients with the communities around them, blurring lines between home and hospital.

media.caption: The Hogeweyk dementia village in Weesp, Netherlands, opened in 2009 as a new model for treating people with dementia. The facility resembles a quaint Dutch village, with a town square, restaurant and other amenities.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Pop and Rock Music;Buffett, Jimmy;Margaritaville Holdings LLC;Key West (Fla)
results.title: Jimmy Buffett, Roguish Bard of Island Escapism, Is Dead at 76
results.abstract: With songs like “Margaritaville” and “Cheeseburger in Paradise,” he became a folk hero to fans known as Parrot Heads. He also became a millionaire hundreds of times over.

media.caption: Jimmy Buffett in 1977. He found a way of life in the Caribbean and Key West, Fla., writing songs peopled with beach bums and barflies.

results.adx_keywords: Personal Finances;Credit and Debt;Women and Girls;Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
results.title: For Women With Money Issues, an A.D.H.D. Diagnosis Can Be Revelatory
results.abstract: A diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in adulthood has solved a mystery for some women, helping them get control over their finances.

media.caption: After racking up $15,000 in debt, Ellyce Fulmore was diagnosed with A.D.H.D. in December 2020.
media.copyright: Todd Korol for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Long Covid;Chronic Condition (Health);Elderly;Therapy and Rehabilitation;Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns
results.title: Long Covid Poses Special Challenges for Seniors
results.abstract: Older people are less likely to be diagnosed but more likely to experience certain kinds of illnesses, research suggests.

media.caption: Patricia Anderson, who has endured 40 months of long Covid symptoms, on a folding seat cane that she now uses for stability. “I was very sick for a long time, and I never really got better,” she said.
media.copyright: Emily Elconin for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Conservatism (US Politics);Clergy;Encyclicals;Francis;Roman Catholic Church;La Civilta Cattolica
results.title: Pope’s Remarks on ‘Reactionary’ U.S. Catholics Rankle, and Resonate
results.abstract: Where Francis sees rigid ideology replacing faith in the conservative American Catholic hierarchy, his critics see a struggle to preserve traditions and teachings they saw as settled.

media.caption: Pope Francis at the weekly general at the Vatican on Wednesday.

results.title: 5 Stand-Up Specials to Stream for the Labor Day Weekend
results.abstract: Todd Barry, Tracy Morgan, Sasheer Zamata, Chris Fleming and Jared Freid riff on weird characters, middle age, lost histories and more.

media.caption: Todd Barry is a master of sarcasm in his new special, “Domestic Shorthair.”

results.title: Trapped in Mud, Burning Man Attendees Are Told to Conserve Food
results.abstract: As the festival in the remote Nevada desert became encased in mud after heavy rains on Friday night, the police opened an investigation on Saturday into the death of an attendee.

media.caption: Thousands of attendees at the Burning Man festival in a remote stretch of the Black Rock Desert in Nevada were told to conserve food, water and fuel as heavy rainfall trapped them in thick mud.

results.title: China to Its People: Spies Are Everywhere, Help Us Catch Them
results.abstract: As Beijing tries to enlist the “whole of society” to guard against foreign enemies, the line between vigilance and paranoia fades.

media.caption: Surveillance cameras in Shanghai in March.

results.adx_keywords: Rain;Burning Man Festival;Floods;Black Rock Desert (Nev)
results.byline: By Finn-Olaf Jones, Anna Betts and Amanda Holpuch
results.title: Amid Rain and Mud, Climactic ‘Burn’ Is Delayed at Burning Man Fest
results.abstract: Officials urged campers to conserve food and water on Sunday, as the police investigated one death. The annual burning of a manlike figure was postponed.

results.adx_keywords: Area Planning and Renewal;Urban Areas;internal-open-access-from-nl;Patrick Bernard;Paris (France)
results.title: Parisians Are Pledging Allegiance to the ‘Republic of Super Neighbors.’ They Must Bring Cheese.
results.abstract: A grass-roots movement aims to recast urban living in Paris and other cities around the world through a hyperlocal prism of neighborliness.

media.caption: Patrick Bernard, the founder of the Republic of Super Neighbors in Paris, center background, with participants in the 14th arrondissement. He encourages neighbors who interact five times daily to do so 50 times a day.
media.copyright: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

media.caption: Billie Eilish’s song “What Was I Made For?” has become the anthem of anxious and depressed young women.

results.title: Stop Resisting Change
results.abstract: With the right mind-set, adapting to change can be a force for growth.

results.title: Bill Richardson, Champion of Americans Held Overseas, Dies at 75
results.abstract: After serving in Congress and as governor of New Mexico, he practiced quasi-public and freelance diplomacy, often with considerable success.

media.caption: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico in his office in 2010. He served two terms, from 2003 to 2011, and at the time was the nation’s only Hispanic governor.
media.copyright: Mark Holm for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Student Loans;Personal Finances;Content Type: Service;Education Department (US)
results.title: Student Loan Payments Are Due Again. Here Are 5 Things to Know.
results.abstract: A three-year payment pause ends in October. A more affordable repayment plan is available, and some borrowers will receive a fresh start.

media.caption: The Georgetown University campus. During an adjustment period from Oct. 1 to Sept. 31, 2024, borrowers won’t be considered delinquent if they miss a payment on their federal student loan.
media.copyright: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

results.title: By Abandoning Civics, Colleges Helped Create the Culture Wars

results.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
results.title: Why Did a Drug Gang Kill 43 Students? Text Messages Hold Clues.
results.abstract: The Mexican police, military officers and others secretly colluded with a cartel that kidnapped 43 students, a case unsolved after nearly a decade. Wiretaps show just how much the authorities helped the cartel behind the mass abduction, and what led to it.
des_facet: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
org_facet: Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)

media.caption: Posters in Mexico City of some of the 43 students who were kidnapped in 2014 by the police and turned over to a cartel.
media.copyright: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Shipwrecks (Historic);Lake Michigan;Wisconsin
results.title: A Ship That Sank in 1881 Is Found Nearly Intact in Lake Michigan
results.abstract: Trinidad, built in 1867, was part of the lucrative grain trade on the Great Lakes. Its remarkably intact wreckage, which included stacks of dishes, was just discovered.

media.caption: In July, shipwreck hunters discovered the intact remains of the schooner Trinidad, which sank off Wisconsin in Lake Michigan in 1881.
media.copyright: Tamara Thomsen/State Historical Society of Wisconsin, via Associated Press
